title-group.article-title: Feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a patient-centered self-care intervention for adults with coronary heart disease in a low resource setting

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: Coronary heart disease (CHD) remains a leading cause of global morbidity and mortality, with disproportionate impact in low resource contexts. Despite the importance of effective self-care in improving outcomes, existing interventions are often fragmented, disease-focused, and lack contextual relevance. This study aimed to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a nurse-led, patient-centered self-care intervention (PCSI) for individuals with CHD in Pakistan.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A mixed-methods study was conducted between May 17 to August 16, 2024 in inpatient department of public hospital in Pakistan. The intervention, developed through literature review and stakeholder input, involved a 2-h individualized education and counselling session delivered one day before discharge. Effectiveness was evaluated using a one-group pretest-posttest design, assessing self-efficacy and self-care behaviors at baseline and four weeks post-discharge. Feasibility was explored through post-intervention interviews with 12 participants. Quantitative data were analyzed using descriptive statistics and Wilcoxon signed-rank test in SPSS, while qualitative data were analyzed manually through content analysis.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Thirty-seven participants (mean age 50.67 ± 6.04 years; 32 men) completed the study. Self-efficacy improved significantly, with mean scores increasing from 76.75 ± 19.65 to 99.86 ± 0.82 (Z = −4.864, p < 0.001). Significant improvements were observed in self-care behaviors across all domains (p < 0.001). Qualitative findings confirmed the intervention's feasibility, relevance and acceptability, while suggesting family engagement, and ongoing support.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The PCSI demonstrated promising effectiveness and feasibility, supporting its potential integration into routine care. Future adaptations could enhance sustained self-care and clinical outcomes in low-resource settings.

list-item.p: Mixed-method study shows feasibility and effectiveness of patient-centered selfcare intervention.
Intervention was co-designed to ensure cultural relevance and patient engagement.
Participants reported high acceptability and satisfaction with the intervention.
Family involvement and ongoing support were suggested to enhance intervention impact.
Findings support potential scale-up of patient-centered self-care in low-resource settings.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) remain the leading cause of mortality worldwide, responsible for over 20.5 million deaths in the year 2021 alone (Di Cesare et al., 2024). Among CVDs, chronic conditions like coronary heart disease (CHD) also known as ischemic heart disease (IHD) constitute a significant portion of global mortality, accounting for 17.8 million deaths annually (Dadkhah and Sharain, 2022). The burden is significantly higher in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), where 80 % of CVD-related deaths occur, with South Asia bearing the highest risk and CHD being the region's leading cause of death (Roth et al., 2020).

Pakistan, a LMIC with a population exceeding 240 million, has an alarming CHD prevalence of 26.9 %, affecting one in four middle-aged adults (Jafar et al., 2005). In year 2020 alone, CHD caused 240,720 deaths in Pakistan, with its rising burden increasing the risk of morbidity and placing immense strain on country's under-resourced healthcare system (Qureshi et al., 2025; Hafeez et al., 2023). Several factors contribute to this burden, including the high prevalence of hypertension (37 %), diabetes (30.8 %), and obesity (23 %), along with unhealthy behaviors such as poor dietary choices, physical inactivity and smoking (Samad and Hanif, 2023). These modifiable risk factors not only increase health risks but also impose significant economic burden due to frequent hospitalizations, invasive treatments, and associated healthcare costs. (Khan et al., 2024; Walker et al., 2018)

With growing burden of CHD in Pakistan, and global evidence supporting self-management, a shift towards preventive and self-care strategies is essential (Riegel et al., 2017a). Risk factor modification, alongside interventions that strengthen self-efficacy (SE) and promote sustainable self-care behaviors (SCB), has the potential to improve health outcomes and reduce economic strain associated with CHD (Katch and Mead, 2010). A patient-centered approach is crucial in this context, as it empowers individuals to manage their condition while addressing personal, behavioral, psychosocial and cultural factors that influence self-management (Marques et al., 2021). This approach is grounded in established behavioral and nursing theories, including Bandura's Self-Efficacy Theory, which highlights the role of confidence in performing health behaviors (Bandura and Adams, 1977; Jeng and Braun, 1994), and Orem's Self-Care Deficit Nursing Theory, which emphasizes nurses' role in supporting patient self-care when individuals are unable to meet their own needs (Orem, 2001; Timmins and Horan, 2007). By adopting patient-centered approach, healthcare providers, particularly nurses, can better support individuals in managing CHD while mitigating its long-term impact on healthcare system and economy (Buawangpong et al., 2020).

Nurses, play a pivotal role in promoting patient-centered care strategies that empower individuals to manage their condition effectively (Alshehri et al., 2022). Nurses, with their knowledge and expertise, equip patients with essential skills needed for effective self-management (Chiang et al., 2018). Additionally, nurses as trusted caregivers, also address psychosocial and cultural barriers through empathetic communication and culturally sensitive care, promoting sustained self-management (Araki, 2019). While evidence from high-income countries supports effectiveness of nurse-led patient-centered care interventions, emerging studies from South Asia and other LMICs indicate variable effectiveness, highlighting the influence of local cultural, social, and healthcare contexts, yet systematic evidence remains limited. Tailored interventions that integrate individual preferences, address behavioral and social factors, and consider cultural and social factors such as family roles, health literacy, and gender norms can effectively bridge this gap. This study aimed to develop, and assess the effectiveness and feasibility of a nurse-led patient-centered self-care intervention (PCSI) in improving SE and SCB of individuals with CHD in Pakistan.

sec.title: Study design
sec.p: This study employed a mixed-methods approach, comprising quantitative and qualitative components. The quantitative component utilized a one group pre-test post-test quasi experimental design to assess the preliminary effectiveness of PCSI. The qualitative component employed an exploratory descriptive design to evaluate the feasibility by capturing participants' experiences with PCSI implementation.

sec.title: Setting and duration
sec.p: The study was carried out at in-patient department of public tertiary care hospital in central Punjab Pakistan, a low-resource setting with limited access to specialized cardiovascular care. The hospital serves a diverse patient population from urban and rural areas, reflecting the broader socio-economic and cultural context of the region. This setting provided an opportunity to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of a culturally tailored, nurse-led PCSI within a resource-constrained healthcare system typical of many LMICs.
The duration of study spanned over four months, from May 17 to August 16, 2024.

sec.title: Population, sampling and sample size
sec.p: The study included hospitalized CHD patients who met the following criteria: (1) Aged 18 to 60 years, (2) presence of CVD risk factors including Hypertension (HTN), Diabetes Mellitus (DM) and Active smoking status, (3) ability to understand Urdu. Patients were excluded if they had: (1) critical condition (i.e. severe pain, hemodynamic instability), (2) active psychiatric illness requiring medication, (3) cognitive impairment (i.e. dementia, learning disability), or (4) non-cardiac comorbidities interfering with participation (i.e. cancer, end-stage renal disease). Participants were selected through consecutive sampling.

The sample size for the quantitative component was determined using G*Power software ver. 3.1, employing an a priori power analysis for a paired-sample t-test. The effect size was estimated based on findings from a previous similar study (Song, 2003). Parameters for the analysis included a one-tailed test, an alpha error probability (α) of 0.05, and a statistical power (1–β) of 0.80. The analysis yielded a required sample size of 34 participants. To account for an anticipated 10 % attrition rate, the final target sample size was increased to 37 participants.
For qualitative component, all participants who completed the post-test data collection were invited for post-intervention interviews, 12 agreed to participate.

sec.title: Quantitative data collection
sec.p: Eligible participants, identified through medical records based on inclusion and exclusion criteria, were approached and invited to participate in this study. Written informed consent was obtained from those who agreed, followed by baseline data collection covering participants' sociodemographic and clinical characteristics including age, gender, education, employment, monthly income, marital status, living area and arrangements, family involvement in care, disease duration, hospital stay duration, weight, BMI, history of HTN, DM, smoking, diet and exercise.

Following baseline data collection, a pre-test was conducted to assess SE and SCB. To minimize potential bias, data were collected by an independent data collector who was not involved in delivering the intervention. SE was assessed using Self-Care Self-Efficacy Scale (SC-SES), a 10-item self-reported tool developed by Riegel and collogues (Yu et al., 2021). SCB were assessed using Self-Care Coronary Heart Disease Inventory (SC-CHDI), including 23-items across three sub-scales: self-care maintenance, self-care monitoring with symptom recognition, and self-care management with treatment effectiveness (Vaughan Dickson et al., 2017). Given that Urdu is Pakistan's national language, both SC-SES and SC-CHDI were translated into Urdu, with original authors' permission and adhering to their recommended translation procedures. The translated versions were pilot tested on 17 eligible patients recruited from the study hospital, however not included in the main study sample. Internal consistency reliability was evaluated using Cronbach α, yielding values of 0.95 and 0.87 for SC-SES and SC-CHDI respectively, confirming their suitability for data collection.

Following pre-test data collection, participants received the Patient-Centered Self-care Intervention (PCSI), grounded in patient-centered care principles (Goldfarb et al., 2024). The intervention was designed after a thorough literature review, observations and interviews with the stakeholders (cardiologists, cardiology nurses, nutritionists, psychologist, and CHD patients). The contents of PCSI were informed by American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines and World Health Organization (WHO)’ HEARTS Technical Package for CVD management in primary care (Riegel et al., 2017b; World Health Organization, 2020). The PCSI was delivered by the principal investigator (PI), a trained cardiology nurse. It consisted of 2-h face-to-face individualized education and counselling session, conducted in simple, cultural congruent language, a day before the participant's discharge. The post-test data were collected during a follow-up visit four weeks after discharge. To ensure intervention fidelity during the session, the PI followed a standardized delivery protocol, using a checklist to cover all components consistently. During the follow-up period, adherence to behavioral changes and intervention fidelity were reinforced through weekly phone calls and frequent SMS reminders. No deviations from the protocol were observed.

sec.title: Qualitative data collection
sec.p:
The participants who completed post-test data collection, were invited to provide post-intervention interviews to explore and understand their experiences with PCSI. After obtaining participants' consent for post-intervention interviews, a mutually agreed date and time were scheduled for a one-on-one interview. The interviews were conducted in a setting preferred by the participants, either in their home or in a designated room at study hospital, ensuring privacy, comfort, and minimal interruptions. The interviews were conducted in Urdu language, with each interview lasting approximately 30 to 45 min, providing sufficient time to share detailed and in-depth responses. All interviews were conducted by a trained researcher with expertise in qualitative interviews, ensuring consistency and the appropriate use of probing to elicit rich data. To avoid any influence, PI who administered the intervention, was not involved in the interview process. To enhance qualitative rigor, detailed field notes were taken, and member checking was employed to validate participant perspectives.

sec.title: Quantitative data analysis
sec.p: The data were first reviewed for inconsistencies and missing information. Sociodemographic and clinical characteristics of the participants were summarized using mean and standard deviation (±SD) for continuous variables and frequency with percentage for categorical variables. For analyzing SE and SCB, a standardized score was computed by first calculating a raw scale score, which was then transformed into a standardized score ranging from 0 to 100. The Wilcoxon Signed-Rank test was used to evaluate the effect of PCSI on SE and SCB, as the visual inspection and statistical analysis through Shapiro-Wilk test indicated non-normal data distribution. A p-value ≤0.05 was considered statistically significant. All analyses were conducted using the Statistical Package for tSocial Sciences (SPSS) version 25.0.

sec.title: Qualitative data analysis
sec.p: Data analysis began with the transcription of interview recordings, which were then carefully reviewed to ensure accuracy. The interviews were translated in English language by a bilingual expert fluent in both Urdu and English to provide an accurate and contextually appropriate translation. Creswell's five-step manual content analysis method was employed to analyze interviews data (Glasgow et al., 2006).

sec.title: Ethical considerations
sec.p: The study was approved by the Ethics Review Committee and Advance Studies Research Board of the University of Health Sciences Lahore, Pakistan (Reference No. UHS/DPS/23.526 dated January 30, 2024). Written permission was sought from hospital administration of the study hospital. Written informed consent was obtained from all participants after providing a comprehensive briefing on the study's purpose, data collection and procedures involved. They were assured of confidentiality and informed of their right to withdraw from at any stage of the study without any consequences for their care at the hospital. All raw data were stored securely on a password-protected personal computer accessible only to the research team. All participants received briefing about the study objectives, potential risks, and anticipated benefits before providing written informed consent.

sec.title: Sample description
sec.p: All 37 participants enrolled in the study completed both the intervention and post-test data collection. The participants' ages ranged from 40 to 60 years, with a mean age of 50.67 (SD ± 6.04) years. The majority (86.5 %) were men, while 5 (13.5 %) were women. All participants were married, with majority (62.2 %) residing in urban areas. Regarding employment status, mostly (78.4 %) were employed, while 8 (21.6 %) were unemployed. Most participants (97.3 %) lived with their families except one who lived alone. With regards to economic status distribution, majority (59.5 %) were classified as ‘Below Middle’, indicating a low socioeconomic condition. Educational levels varied, with majority (73.0 %) having primary education or below.

Clinical characteristics revealed that participants' weight ranged from 50 kg to 115 kg, with a mean of 75.8 kg (SD ± 13.3). The BMI ranged from 17.40 to 38.50, with a mean of 26.47 (SD ± 4.16). Among the participants, 2.7 % were underweight, 10.8 % had a normal weight, 62.2 % were overweight, and 24.3 % were classified as obese. Hospital stay duration varied, with mostly (78.4 %) participants staying for 3 to 5 days, 13.5 % for 5 to 7 days, and 8.1 % for more than 7 days. Physical activity levels revealed that majority (94.6 %) of participants did not engage in regular physical activity. Dietary patterns indicated that mostly (78.4 %) participants have a normal fat intake. Table 3 outlines the sociodemographic and clinical characteristics of the participants. sec.title: Quantitative results
sec.p:
The effect of PCSI on SE and SCB was evaluated using the Wilcoxon Signed-Rank Test to analyze differences between pre-test and post-test SE and SCB scores. For SE, the results revealed a statistically significant improvement from pre-test to post-test scores. The pre-test mean score of 76.75 ± 19.65, with a median of 82.50, increased to 99.86 ± 0.82, with a median of 100.0. This change was statistically significant (p < 0.001), indicating an improvement in participants' self-efficacy following the PCSI. (see Table 4).Table 4

The corresponding Z-statistics for each comparison were as follows: Self-Efficacy (Z = −4.864), Self-Care Maintenance (Z = −5.234), Self-Care Monitoring (Z = −5.235), Symptom Recognition (Z = −4.389), Self-Care Management (Z = −4.791), and Treatment Effectiveness (Z = −4.397).

With regards to the analysis of SCB, significant improvements were observed in all domains following the PCSI. Table 4 shows that self-care maintenance scores increased from a pre-test mean of 54.31 ± 19.35 (median = 52.70) to a post-test mean of 98.79 ± 2.14 (median = 100.0; p < 0.001). Similarly, self-care monitoring scores rose from 60.37 ± 19.37 (median = 60.70) to 97.86 ± 4.19 (median = 100.0; p < 0.001). Symptom recognition also improved significantly, with scores increasing from 49.73 ± 29.67 (median = 60.00) to 97.14 ± 16.90 (median = 100.0; p < 0.001). Self-care management scores increased from 76.12 ± 22.67 (median = 80.00) to 99.86 ± 0.82 (median = 100.0; p < 0.001). The final item, treatment effectiveness, showed a marked improvement from 77.84 ± 23.94 (median = 80.00) to 100.0 ± 0.00 (median = 100.0; p < 0.001). These findings indicate that the PCSI significantly enhanced SE and SCB across all measured domains. However, the consistently high post-test scores suggest a potential ceiling effect, which should be considered when interpreting these results.

sec.title: Qualitative findings
sec.p: The manual content analysis of post-intervention interviews conducted with 12 participants provided valuable insights into the feasibility of PCSI across four focus areas: content, delivery, acceptability, and sustainability. Overall, participants shared positive experiences with the intervention, indicating its feasibility and effectiveness in meeting their self-care needs. However, several areas for improvement were also identified.

With regards to the content, participants generally found the content of intervention helpful, clear, and understandable. The participants found the structured information on disease, its risk factors, symptom recognition, and self-management very clear and tailored to their needs. One participant noted: “The guidance on choosing my diet and managing my dietary habits was especially helpful and easy to apply in my daily routine. (P-M3)”.

However, a few participants suggested adding more visual aids to enhance understanding for individuals with lower literacy levels. For example, a participant stated: “It would have been better if there were more pictures to explain points. (P-M11)”.

Regarding the delivery of PCSI, most participants expressed satisfaction with both its timing and the convenience of receiving it at bedside, emphasizing that having the intervention scheduled before their discharge was particularly beneficial, as it aligned with their transition from hospital to self-care at home. Many described the two-hour duration as sufficient and manageable. One participant commented: “Having the session at my bedside made it more personal. After all it was for my own health and wellbeing. (P-M9)”.

The role of the cardiology nurse delivering the intervention was praised for clarity and approachability. As one participant shared: “The nurse was excellent at explaining things step by step and made sure I understood everything before moving on. (P-M13)”.

A few participants suggested scheduling the intervention into shorter sessions rather than two-hour session to enhance retention and allow time for reflection. One participant expressed: “I think keeping more sessions, breaking these two into shorter ones would be better. It's hard to absorb everything in two hours. (P-F3)”.

Focusing acceptability, PCSI was perceived as acceptable and personalized. Many participants appreciated the individualized focus and the opportunity to ask questions tailored to their specific needs and condition. A participant reflected: “I felt the session was made just for me, it really addressed my issues. (P-M9)”.

Regarding sustainability, participants recognized the potential for long-term benefits of PCSI, particularly in helping them adopt healthier lifestyle behaviors. Most participants reported that they had maintained positive changes in their diet and physical activity. One participant remarked: “I have been following the dietary advice and exercise since discharge, and I feel much better. (P-M5)”.

However, challenges in sustaining behavioral changes were also noted, particularly for smoking cessation. Some participants expressed the need for ongoing support to reinforce smoking cessation. One participant verbalized: “Quitting smoking has been tough for me. Some follow-up sessions might help me stay motivated. (P-M9)”.

Some participants found it challenging to maintain diet control due to the cultural norm of having meals together as a family. They suggested involving family to foster collective understanding and support for healthier eating habits. As one participant expressed, “It's difficult to maintain diet control when we all eat together. I cook for everyone, and making something just for myself feels odd. But I know that eating healthy benefits the whole family, so having sessions with them would really help. (P-F2)”.

Overall, the qualitative findings confirm the feasibility of PCSI in a low-resource setting, with participants valuing its relevance, clarity, perceived benefits and personalized bedside delivery. While PCSI was effective in enhancing SE and SCB, improvements in delivery format including splitting the sessions into shorter segments for better retention, involving family members to support dietary adherence, and providing continued guidance and ongoing support for smoking cessation could enhance its long-term impact and sustainability.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study found that PCSI significantly enhanced SE and SCB of individuals with CHD. Qualitative insights confirmed its feasibility and identified areas for improvement, including delivery format, family involvement and ongoing support for long-term impact. These findings align with existing evidence supporting patient-centered self-care interventions in chronic disease management (Chiang et al., 2018; Creswell and Poth, 2016; Lee et al., 2022).

The quantitative results indicated a significant improvement in SE and SCB following PCSI. These findings are consistent with previous studies demonstrating the impact of structured self-care interventions on improving health outcomes in patients with CHD (Song, 2003; Asmat et al., 2022). SE is a crucial determinant of sustained behavioral change, and its enhancement through PCSI suggests long-term benefits for effective disease management. Given that enhanced SE and SCB are associated with reduced hospital readmissions and better clinical outcomes (Shin and Khim, 2002), these findings highlight the potential of PCSI as an effective strategy for improving CHD management in resource-limited settings. However, the very high post-test scores also suggest a potential ceiling effect, which may have limited the measurable range of improvement and should be considered when interpreting the magnitude of the improvements. Future studies could address this by including longer follow-up periods, larger sample sizes, or more sensitive measurement tools to better capture sustained changes and avoid ceiling effects.

The qualitative findings confirmed the feasibility of PCSI in a low-resource setting, with participants valuing its relevance, clarity, and personalized bedside delivery. The timing of the intervention was perceived as particularly beneficial, as it allowed participants to transition smoothly to self-care at home. Similar studies have emphasized the importance of tailored discharge interventions in improving patient’ adherence to self-care at home (Riegel et al., 2021). With regards, to areas of improvement, participants suggested restructuring the intervention into shorter sessions to improve retention, which aligns with research indicating that breaking down educational and behavioral training sessions enhances engagement and comprehension (Posadas-Collado et al., 2022). Others highlighted cultural barriers to dietary changes, noting the challenge of maintaining diet control within a family setting. This highlights the need to involve family members in self-care education, a strategy that has shown to improve adherence in similar interventions. Additionally, participants emphasized the importance of ongoing post-discharge support, reinforcing evidence that continued follow-up interventions contribute to sustained behavioral change (Riegel et al., 2017b; Nemec and McKown, 2024).

In Pakistan, a country facing rising burden of CHD, with constrained healthcare resources and in-adequate patient education, PCSI presents a viable approach to enhancing SE and SCB, thus effective disease management. The PCSI's effectiveness and feasibility suggest that it can be scaled up to benefit a broader population, provided that certain modifications, such as involving family members, adapting session structures, and integrating follow-up support, are incorporated. Furthermore, integrating PCSI into existing healthcare systems, such as nurse-led discharge planning and community-based follow-up programs, could enhance sustainability and ensure that benefits are maintained over time. Embedding the intervention within routine care pathways and training nurses to deliver PCSI may support scalability in resource-constrained settings.

This study's strengths include its mixed-methods approach, which provided a comprehensive understanding of PCSI's impact by integrating quantitative outcomes with qualitative insights. However, limitations include the study's reliance on self-reported data, which may introduce response bias, and its focus on a specific population from a single hospital, potentially limiting generalizability. Additionally, the short follow-up period of four weeks may not capture the sustainability of observed changes, and the absence of a control group may limit the ability to draw causal inferences.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study supports the preliminary effectiveness and feasibility of PCSI in improving SE and SCB among adults with CHD in a resource-constrained setting. While beneficial, its impact could be enhanced through shorter sessions, greater family involvement, and ongoing support. Clinically, the findings suggest that nurse-led, patient-centered interventions can be integrated into routine care to strengthen self-management and improve CHD outcomes. At a policy level, scaling up PCSI within healthcare systems in LMICs may optimize resources and ease the burden on overstretched services. Future research should assess its long-term sustainability, comparative effectiveness, and potential for broader implementation across diverse settings.
